author: bridge-bot
content: <Marcin> Right, so thinking from first principles ‚Äì what do we lose by permitting any redirect url? We enable independent (including malicious) frontends to mediate between users and the backend. That is usually a bad thing, because typically apps have one frontend, owned by the same org as the backend. Hence OAuth recommends you use an explicit permit-list. We actually want independent (potentially malicious) clients to be able to participate. Malicious frontends are not a problem at all ‚Äì they can't harm the user (we don't have any user resources in the backend anyway) & they can't harm us (we get some useless contributions is all). So we can give up on the permit list without sacrificing security.

<kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  The RFC states:

```
`Before directing the resource owner back to the client with the
authorization code, the authorization server authenticates the
resource owner and obtains authorization.  Because the resource owner
```
